author: bigbenbeer
title: UTXO Optimizer and Scheduler
description: Concurrency with UTXOs is a tricky problem that is difficult to solve and adds to transaction load unnecessarily.

f6_assessments.q0: Yes, the proposal addresses the challenge setting by improving the experience of developers when interacting with the cardano-cli and creating UTXO transactions.  the deliverable is a math model of how to best batch transactions together and manage the problem of concurrency it will not implement the model in any language which will be up to the developers to decide what language to use. The research will be done at an advanced level and the proposer aims to publish his conclusions in an academic journal.  As a developer I think this is a great idea as there has been a number of implementations of how to deal with concurrency. Some examples are MinSwap and SundaySwap DEXs; however the hasn't been an academic-level research paper on this. I do have a few that the developers would primarily benefit from having a working implementation in a programming language that they could get started with.  The proposal might come back additional funding if there is scope to develop project further.
f6_assessments.q1: The project will be delivered by Benjamin Beer, who has a formal computer and electronic engineering education with a focus on hardware and software programming and system design. Ben provides a link to his LinkedIn profile and the list of academic achievements in the past years.  Ben is currently a postgraduate student and will be developing this project as part of his academic research. Ben is also the CTO of Revelar, which is a startup funded by Catalyst. Ben has the skills to complete this project and has experience working with Cardano. The budget is set very conservatively at just over $3,000 and would be used to cover the tuition and other campus fees. Benjamin does not pretend to make a profit on this project but rather use it in his thesis. Ben aims to deliver this within three months and the timeline is split into three sections. In the first section he will deliver a literature review and a problem statements; in the the second section he will deliver a math model with relevant simulation and preliminary results; in the 3rd section he will deliver a paper and code base with the expectation that the paper will make it into a publication. There is no discussion of the language or the architecture as this will primarily be a math model. The provided git repo repository was empty as of the 5th of July. The Proposal discusses a number of risks that could derail this deliverable. One of the risks is that the project scope is too small, or the development takes much longer than expected, that he becomes a bad student and cannot deliver. He then goes on to provide the mitigation actions for each of the risks.  I'm confident that Benjamin will be able to deliver a math model; even though I would have liked that, he also did a demo implementation in a programming language

f6_assessments.q0: The proposal aims to build a mathematical model that optimized UTXO use while building transactions, and a Javascript/Python script that uses this model. The proposer explains the problem very well and in good detail. UTXOs are at the heart of Cardano. They grant many scalability benefits, in theory. In practice, building transactions is done using the Cardano-CLI, and is quite difficult to do. As the proposer suggests, we need an optimized algorithm to select which UTXOs to use in any give transaction. This will truly allow Cardano's scalability to shine. It will also allow developers to use a trusted open source algorithm to use when building transactions, lowering the barriers in developing for some of the more complicated use cases like DEXes, marketplaces, etc. The proposal is very much inline with the challenge, as it will make developers' lives easier building transactions in complex use cases. This is very useful since building transactions is generally thought to be the most time consuming and difficult part of developing on Cardano. The proposal will also be part of the proposers' Post-grad Degree in Industrial Engineering and will result in a public IP research paper. We love those papers at Cardano, so matches well with the vision too.
f6_assessments.q1:
The budget is set at a measly 3854.09 USD, only covering education expenses. The proposer notes he doesn't want funding for anything other than the expenses. The plan is simple with three milestones: 1 - delivery of literature review, thesis, and problem statement, 2 - delivery of math model, simulation, preliminary results, 3 - completed academic paper and code base. From step 1 to 3 it spans about 70 days. This seems to me a tight schedule to deliver, but since this is part of an academic research, I'm guessing the work is already underway. 

The proposer is a Computer and Electronic Engineering major. He has extensive background in data processing, optimizing, and application of blockchains in supply chains. He's the CTO of Revelar, a Cardano based gaming company. They have 10 proposals on Fund 7, 10 on Fund 8, and 2 on Fund 9 (This proposal is not a Revelar proposal). 4 of these F7 proposals, and 2 of the F8 proposals have been funded. I assume the proposer is working on all of these, as the entire team is made up of 3 people by the information on their website. There is no information provided as to how he'll manage workload with other proposals. These seem to be small proposals, so I don't think there'll be a big issue, yet this info should have been provided nonetheless. 

Overall, there is schedule and workload questions that are unanswered, but from what I've seen in the proposer's work, I believe he can deliver, maybe on a slightly delayed schedule.
f6_assessments.q2: The proposal has an open source github repository from which progress will be publicly seen by anyone interested. If allowed, the proposer will also post graded documents as these will show academic progress on the work. The proposer will also conduct check-in meetings and reports, although there is no information provided as to which communication channel these will be conducted through. The proposal is clear in what it will do, by when, and the output to be produced. It is a research project, with the aim of creating a research paper to be published in a respectable journal. This is a good definition of success but I think it's incomplete. The main point of this research is optimizing and scheduling UTXOs. There should be a metric to measure how successful that is. This will certainly be a part of the research paper, but I think it should have been mentioned here as well. It should definitely be reported as part of the check-in meetings and reports mentioned.
